abstract.p: CUNY Chancellor Matthew Goldstein letter on decline in number of welfare recipients attending CUNY (Setp 13 article)

block.p: Re ''Freshman Class Grows at CUNY, Reversing Trend'' (front page, Sept. 13):

You correctly reported that I said the City University of New York lost more than 20,000 students on public assistance when New York City began to require welfare recipients to work. As a statistician, I note that during the same period, the overall number of city residents supported by social services dramatically declined, consistent with reforms in government policies at all levels.
Re ''Freshman Class Grows at CUNY, Reversing Trend'' (front page, Sept. 13):

You correctly reported that I said the City University of New York lost more than 20,000 students on public assistance when New York City began to require welfare recipients to work. As a statistician, I note that during the same period, the overall number of city residents supported by social services dramatically declined, consistent with reforms in government policies at all levels.

It is therefore not surprising that substantially fewer public assistance recipients attended CUNY. But we do not know if they received training or education elsewhere, if some enrolled or re-enrolled at CUNY after they left the welfare rolls, or if they obtained full-time employment.
MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN Chancellor City University of New York New York, Sept. 18, 2000
